author: By Daniel Victor
title: Four People Fatally Stabbed in London
description: A suspect was in custody Monday morning, and the police say they believe the attacker and the victims knew each other.
content: Three women and a man were fatally stabbed in the London borough of Southwark early Monday, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Adviser Cedric Richmond Is Leaving the White House
description: The former Louisiana congressman is expected to step down next month. He will be one of the first White House senior advisers to leave as Democrats brace for a difficult midterm election.
content: Cedric Richmond, a senior adviser to President Biden, is expected to step down from his position next month, becoming one of the first senior White House aides to leave the administration as Democrats brace for a difficult midterm election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: To tackle inequality, Macron plans a ‘purchasing power package.’
description: PARIS — Vowing to heal France’s “doubts and divisions,” President Emmanuel Macron is expected to turn quickly to tackling one of the key issues that spurred over 40 percent of voters to cast a ballot for the far-right candidate Marine Le Pen: an erosion in purchasing power and living standards that fueled resentment during his first term.
content: PARIS — Vowing to heal France’s “doubts and divisions,” President Emmanuel Macron is expected to turn quickly to tackling one of the key issues that spurred over 40 percent of voters to cast a ballot for the far-right candidate Marine Le Pen: an erosion in purchasing power and living standards that fueled resentment during his first term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Trump Media adds former Devin Nunes aides, Donald Jr. and ‘Apprentice’ contestant as officers.
description: Mr. Nunes stepped down from his House seat in January to become chief executive of Trump Media. Wes Moss, a financial adviser and a contestant on “The Apprentice,” is also now a director.
content: Devin Nunes, the former Republican congressman from California who now heads the social media start-up backed by former President Donald J. Trump, has brought in two former aides as officers in the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Texas Court Halts Execution of Mother Convicted of Killing Child
description: Melissa Lucio had long maintained her innocence. New evidence and expert testimony emerged casting strong doubt on her guilt.
content: HOUSTON — The highest criminal court in Texas on Monday ordered a halt to the execution of a Hispanic mother of 14 convicted of killing her 2-year-old child more than a decade ago in a case that has drawn bipartisan outrage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Savor This Kumquat Compote From La Boîte
description: The Hell’s Kitchen spice store has again worked with the chef Eric Ripert and the preserve-maker Le Bon Magot for this condiment.
content: On the heels of introducing its Tunisian-style preserved lemon condiment, La Boîte, the spice store in Hell’s Kitchen, has collaborated again with the chef Eric Ripert and the preserve-maker Le Bon Magot for its new, sweetly tangy kumquat compote with Cognac. As devoted a cook as you might be, don’t be shy about leaving to others the effort of seeding and cooking kumquats; these are meltingly tender and seasoned with cinnamon and star anise. Warm the contents of the jar to sidle up to duck breast, or serve the compote at room temperature alongside cheese.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Emmanuel Macron, Victorious, Searches for Reinvention
description: France seems in search of a kinder, gentler, greener President Macron. He says he will listen.
content: PARIS — There have been many Emmanuel Macrons: the free-market reformer, the man who nationalized salaries in response to the pandemic, the provocateur who pronounced NATO brain-dead, the maneuverer ever adjusting his position, the diplomat and the disrupter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanna Mitchell
title: Get Ready For the New, Improved Second
description: Scientists are preparing to redefine the fundamental unit of time. It won’t get any longer or shorter, but it will be more precise — and a whole lot more powerful.
content: Modern civilization, it is said, would be impossible without measurement. And measurement would be pointless if we weren’t all using the same units.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy and Charlie Savage
title: Who Ended the Travel Mask Mandate? A Vaccine Critic, a Florida Judge and 2 Anxious Travelers
description: The mask rule on planes and public transportation has been targeted by the travel industry and Republican lawmakers. In the end, it was brought down by a little-known nonprofit, a conservative judge and chance.
content: When the federal mandate requiring masks to be worn on planes and other public transportation crumbled last week, it was not because of lobbying by established trade organizations, or the strident calls of Republican lawmakers, or even a determination by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that masks were no longer necessary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Austin Ramzy
title: Fires rip through Russian oil depots not far from the Ukrainian border.
description: Russian state television reported two separate explosions, but officials acknowledged only one.
content: Large fires tore through oil depots on Monday in Bryansk, a Russian city less than 100 miles from the Ukrainian border that is a key logistical hub in Russia’s war effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelia Herrera
title: ‘Luzifer’ Review: Finding the Devil in Everything
description: A son must save his ailing mother in this disturbing, ambitious religious thriller.
content: In Peter Brunner’s “Luzifer,” a mother and her adult son, Maria and Johannes, live isolated from society in a remote alpine cabin. Maria (Susanne Jensen) is a recovering alcoholic who turned to religion to escape her vices, and imparts the lessons of a pious existence onto Johannes (Franz Rogowski), who functions on the developmental level of a child. The two spend their days subsistence farming, or engaged in deep prayer and sacred rituals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Meta plans to open its first retail store as it highlights metaverse-related products.
description: Meta Store, the company’s first physical storefront, will sell virtual- and augmented-reality devices.
content: Meta, the company formerly known as Facebook, said on Monday that it planned to open its first physical storefront next month, as it works to transform itself into a leader of the metaverse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: QAnonization, Orbanization and Disney
description: Conspiracy-theory politics catches up with Mickey Mouse.
content: Until recently the current confrontation between Disney and the State of Florida would have seemed inconceivable. The attacks by Florida Republicans on the entertainment giant will hurt the state’s economy, possibly severely; they reflect a sudden lurch toward intolerance in a nation that seemed to be growing ever more tolerant; and the allegations against Disney are, in a word, insane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman
title: Rapid Inflation, Lower Employment: How the U.S. Pandemic Response Measures Up
description: The United States spent more on its policy response than other advanced economies. Now economists are revisiting how that worked.
content: The United States spent more aggressively to protect its economy from the pandemic than many global peers, a strategy that has helped to foment more rapid inflation — but also a faster economic rebound and brisk job gains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Emmanuel Macron’s Win Was Also a Win for Louis Vuitton
description: Brigitte Macron continues to champion the brand.
content: Emmanuel Macron’s victory in the French presidential election on Sunday was not just a victory for the young president’s vision of France and its role in the world, or centrism versus the far-right wing, though it was both of those things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: The prospect of lockdowns in Beijing fuels more concerns about supply chain disruptions.
description: China’s capital city is not as central to global production networks as Shanghai, but the costs for global companies will still mount if lockdowns spread.
content: The prospect of further lockdowns in China prompted a fresh wave of economic anxiety on Monday as investors and companies whose supply chains run through China contemplated the impact of 70 new virus cases that the Beijing government said it had detected over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: BuzzFeed argues that employee dispute should be moved to a court.
description: Dozens of employees had accused Buzzfeed of shortchanging them in its public debut.
content: BuzzFeed has asked a court to block arbitration claims from about 90 current and former employees who said they were shortchanged in the company’s public offering, arguing that the accusations should be taken before a court instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Learn About the Chef James Hemings at the Africa Center
description: A program produced by the Museum of Food and Drink in New York will hold a talk and play clips from a 2021 documentary.
content: A talk about James Hemings and clips from a 2021 documentary about him will be part of a program produced by the Museum of Food and Drink in New York, at the Africa Center early next month. Hemings, who was held in slavery by Thomas Jefferson, learned French cooking on a trip to Paris and eventually became Jefferson’s chef de cuisine. Hemings is credited with bringing French food back to Monticello, Jefferson’s residence in Virginia, including the recipe for macaroni and cheese. Attendees will be able to snack on that recipe; the program can also be streamed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
title: Biden Announces Ambassador Pick for Ukraine After Months of Delay
description: The U.S. Embassy, which closed just before Russia’s invasion, could reopen “over a couple of weeks,” Secretary of State Antony Blinken said.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s pick for ambassador to Ukraine will bolster relations between Washington and Kyiv after years without a Senate-confirmed envoy in the post, veteran diplomats say, but a return to a U.S. diplomatic presence during a war brings new risk for the Biden administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Tylor Megill and Mets Cruise Through Win Over D’Backs
description: The Mets won their fifth straight series. Japanese sensation Roki Sasaki, meanwhile, saw his streak of perfection come to an end.
content: PHOENIX — Tylor Megill’s fastball was blazing, J.D. Davis smashed his first homer of the year and the opportunistic Mets won another ballgame by beating the sloppy Arizona Diamondbacks, 6-2, on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Kemp and Perdue Debate, Looking Back at 2020 and Ahead to Abrams
description: Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia and his Republican primary opponent, former Senator David Perdue, bickered over the previous election — and over who would be more likely to defeat Stacey Abrams in November.
content: ATLANTA — Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia and former Senator David Perdue, a former ally who is challenging him in the Republican primary next month, met in an explosive first debate on Sunday night that was marked by a lengthy rehashing of the 2020 election’s outcome and testy attacks each other’s veracity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Anderson
title: Foraging for Ramps With the King of Appalachian Smoked Pork
description: Every spring, Allan Benton heads to the woods of Tennessee to search for alliums and cook up a creekside feast.
content: MADISONVILLE, Tenn. — Allan Benton started selling country hams here in the 1970s, figuring he could make a better living than he did as a high school guidance counselor. His early efforts were not encouraging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Allows Elite High School’s New Admissions Rules
description: A group including parents of Asian American students challenged the new criteria at Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology in Virginia.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday temporarily approved new admissions criteria at an elite public high school in Virginia that eliminated standardized tests, clearing the way for the use of a policy intended to diversify the student body in choosing the class that will enter in the fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Praying the Lakers Regain a Starring Role in the N.B.A. Playoffs
description: This postseason, the only reminders of the Lakers’ luster appear on a fictionalized cable series and streaming documentaries. Perhaps, our columnist writes, divine intervention would help.
content: Dear God of Sports,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: Warren Buffett Faces Renewed Climate Change Challenge by Investors
description: Mr. Buffett has pushed back against investors who want to force Berkshire Hathaway to do more to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
content: Investors concerned about climate change have developed an effective playbook for getting companies to set more ambitious goals for reducing greenhouse gas emissions by pressuring, shaming and cajoling executives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman, Sophie Kasakove, Jill Cowan and Richard Fausset
title: Cities Want to Return to Prepandemic Life. One Obstacle: Transit Crime.
description: Crime rates on trains and buses are up in some of the nation’s biggest cities, one more barrier for downtowns trying to rebound.
content: CHICAGO — For months, Anna Balla, 47, tolerated the unruly behavior she says has become commonplace when riding the “L” downtown: smoking, harassment and even a stranger’s uninvited use of her shoulder to vault himself into a spot in a crowded Chicago train.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Why City Pigeons Are Worth Watching’
description: In this lesson, students will learn everything about pigeons, from their history and behavior to their genetics and predation. Then, they will study the birds in their region.
content: This lesson is a part of our Accessible Activities feature, which aims to welcome a wider variety of learners to our site and to The Times in general. Learn more and tell us what you think here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and Eileen Sullivan
title: Judge Says Migrants Must Still Be Denied Entry for Health Reasons
description: Under a public health rule known as Title 42, thousands of migrants have been expelled at the border. A federal judge is halting efforts to begin lifting the policy, due to end on May 23.
content: A federal judge on Monday said he would block the Biden administration from exempting migrants from expulsion under a Trump-era public health order until the policy is officially lifted next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: A Vinyl Release Returns Tyler, the Creator to No. 1 After 10 Months
description: The long-delayed arrival of “Call Me if You Get Lost” on vinyl sold 49,500 copies, bringing the rapper back to the top of the Billboard 200.
content: Forty-three weeks ago, in June 2021, the rapper, singer and Baudelaire-referencing cultural omnivore Tyler, the Creator released “Call Me if You Get Lost,” his sixth studio album.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Rosé Season Is Around the Corner
description: Get a subscription from Parcelle Wine for three bottles a month from May to September.
content: Perhaps you’re dreaming of summer happy hours and you’ve already ordered a case of your favorite rosé. If not, Parcelle Wine is offering a chance to play the field: Get a subscription for three bottles of rosé each month from May through September. The wines on offer include some highly regarded labels like Tibouren Clos Cibonne, Girolamo Russo Etna Rosato and Domaine Vacheron Sancerre Rosé.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Remember When Kevin McCarthy Had ‘Had It’ With Trump?
description: And does this mean that Ron DeSantis won’t be taking his kids to Disney World anymore?
content: Gail Collins: Bret, I hate to begin with border immigration issues. Asking people “What do you think about Title 42?” isn’t generally the perfect conversation opener.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Jenny Gross, David F. Gallagher and Anna Schaverien
title: The Elon Musk-Twitter Endgame
description: Negotiations ran long into the night as Musk’s offer to buy Twitter and take it private looks increasingly likely to go ahead.
content: What seemed highly improbable a week and a half ago is now looking a lot more real: Twitter is in advanced talks to sell itself to Elon Musk. The company’s 11-member board was negotiating with Musk into the early hours of the morning over his offer to buy the social networking service and take it private, DealBook’s Lauren Hirsch and The Times’s Mike Isaac report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Jon Stewart, Who Revolutionized Political Satire, Wins Humor Award
description: The ceremony for the Mark Twain Prize, one of comedy’s top honors, celebrated Mr. Stewart’s achievements on “The Daily Show” and his activism on behalf of veterans and 9/11 emergency workers.
content: WASHINGTON — Jon Stewart walked onstage at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts on Sunday night serenaded by Bruce Springsteen covering the Beatles’ “Come Together,” in an ode to Mr. Stewart’s long-held aspirations for America, despite his career based on biting political satire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.2 Million Homes in California
description: A Spanish-style home in Los Angeles, a three-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a midcentury ranch house in Kentfield.
content: This house is in Rancho Park, in the Westside neighborhood of Los Angeles. The area takes its name from the park a block from this property, where the Cheviot Hills Recreation Center offers a basketball court and areas dedicated to archery and the French lawn game pétanque.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: 2 Parents Appeal Their Convictions in Varsity Blues Scandal
description: The business executives John B. Wilson and Gamal Abdelaziz each received a long sentence, but in appeals, their lawyers say the key claim against them is legally flawed.
content: Lawyers for a private equity investor and a former casino executive facing federal prison in the college admissions scandal known as Operation Varsity Blues filed appeals on Monday seeking to have their convictions overturned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Big tech earnings and new data on economic growth: The week in Business.
description: Meta, Apple, Amazon and others will report their first-quarter earnings.
content: Tech company earnings: Technology giants including Microsoft, Alphabet, Meta, Amazon and Apple are set to publish their financial performance reports for the first three months of the year. Tech stocks have been losing their ground as investors respond to the Federal Reserve’s plans to raise interest rates this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Chris Bailey, Who Gave Australia Punk Rock, Dies at 65
description: His band, the Saints, introduced the country (and the world) to their raw sound just as the Sex Pistols were emerging in London and the Ramones in New York.
content: Chris Bailey, an Australian singer who with his band, the Saints, introduced their country to the raw, fast-tempo sounds of punk rock in the mid-1970s, just as the Sex Pistols were spiking their hair in London and the Ramones were donning their leather jackets in New York City, died on April 9 in Haarlem, the Netherlands. He was 65.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: How Good Is Your Sense of Direction?
description: Do you use your own internal compass to get from place to place? Or do you depend on a smartphone map?
content: When you go somewhere new in your city or town, how do you get there?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Behind Austin’s Call for a ‘Weakened’ Russia, Hints of a Shift
description: The United States is edging toward a dynamic that pits Washington more directly against Moscow, and one that U.S. officials see as likely to play out for years.
content: WASHINGTON — When Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III declared Monday at the end of a stealth visit to Ukraine that America’s goal is to see Russia so “weakened” that it would no longer have the power to invade a neighboring state, he was acknowledging a transformation of the conflict, from a battle over control of Ukraine to one that pits Washington more directly against Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Mooj Zadie, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Alexandra Leigh Young, Rikki Novetsky, Kaitlin Roberts, John Ketchum, Mike Benoist, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: A Push for Traffic Stop Reform
description: The relatively minor police checks turn lethal in a disproportionate number of cases. But moves to restrict the practice could be hobbled by a rise in violent crime.
content: A Times investigation last year found that minor traffic stops in the United States were far more deadly than widely thought — in the previous five years, 400 unarmed motorists who were not under pursuit for any violent crime were killed by the police during such checks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: When Art Goes Global, It Loses Something
description: The things we create are better when they come out of a specific, lived context.
content: A couple months ago I realized I had written nearly 50 editions of this newsletter and began thinking about what, exactly, I was doing with all these words. The ensuing conversation with myself wasn’t particularly deep and never fringed on anything existential, but it did inspire me to buy a lot of books from famous newspaper columnists of the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Everyday Italian Recipes From Serafina
description: The founders of the New York-based restaurant chain have a new, vibrantly photographed cookbook with all the essentials.
content: In their new cookbook, Vittorio Assaf and Fabio Granato describe the unlikely creation of their still-expanding, New York-based Serafina restaurant chain: While stuck on a stranded catamaran in a storm off Long Island in 1994 they swore they’d open the restaurant if they survived. The vibrantly photographed cookbook based on the restaurants’ dishes describes essential Italian ingredients, and the recipe chapters are like a menu, starting with antipasti and ending with dessert. The richest section is devoted to pasta. They provide fusilli con pesto alla Genovese, which classically includes green beans and potatoes; some minimal but effective combinations of spaghetti with bottarga, and penne with butter and sage; and a cheater’s carbonara that includes cream. The pizza chapter is well-stuffed, heavy on variations of the traditional margherita. Simply roasted meats and vegetables should encourage even a beginner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Safak Timur and Elif Ince
title: Turkish Philanthropist Is Convicted and Sentenced to Life Over Protests
description: Osman Kavala, a well-known activist, was found guilty of charges related to popular protests in 2013.
content: ISTANBUL — A Turkish court on Monday convicted a prominent Turkish philanthropist of trying to violently overthrow the government of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and sentenced him to life in prison without parole, in a case that has been denounced by human rights organizations and has heightened tensions with the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Twitter Employees Search for Answers as Musk Takeover Becomes Reality
description: Workers say they have been left largely in the dark about what a sale to the billionaire will mean for them and their shares in the company.
content: In January 2020, thousands of Twitter employees gathered in Houston for a corporate summit called #OneTeam. During the event, Jack Dorsey, Twitter’s chief executive at the time, revealed he had invited a surprise guest. Then, with a wave and a smile, Elon Musk appeared on giant screens above the stage. The crowd cheered, clapped and pumped fists. “We love you,” one employee shouted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Library of Congress Acquires Neil Simon Papers
description: The collection of approximately 7,700 items, donated by Simon’s widow, includes dozens of unfinished shows, including a screenplay written for Bette Midler and Whoopi Goldberg.
content: As Mark Eden Horowitz, a senior music specialist at the Library of Congress, was digging through the playwright Neil Simon’s manuscripts and papers earlier this year, he made a surprising discovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: F.A.A. Investigating Crash After Midair Pilot-Swapping Stunt
description: Luke Aikins and Andy Farrington planned to send their Cessna 182 planes into tandem nosedives and then jump out midair to switch planes.
content: The Federal Aviation Administration said on Monday that it was investigating a crash after a stunt that called for two pilots to parachute from nose-diving planes and swap cockpits in midair.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Twitter deal could be announced as soon as today.
description: Twitter is nearing a deal to sell itself to Elon Musk, two people with knowledge of the situation said, a move that would unite the world’s richest man with the influential social networking service. An agreement could be announced as soon as Monday, the people told The Times’s Lauren Hirsch, Mike Isaac and Katie Conger.
content: Twitter is nearing a deal to sell itself to Elon Musk, two people with knowledge of the situation said, a move that would unite the world’s richest man with the influential social networking service. An agreement could be announced as soon as Monday, the people told The Times’s Lauren Hirsch, Mike Isaac and Katie Conger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: How Zelensky Tamed Ukraine’s Fractious Politics and Stood Up to Putin
description: Ukrainian politics were known for sharp-elbowed infighting. But as he defends his country against the Russian invasion, President Volodymyr Zelensky has his government presenting a unified front.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Russian tanks were rolling over the border and Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, was in the grips of fear and panic. Street fighting broke out and a Russian armored column, barreling into the city, advanced to within two miles of the office of President Volodymyr Zelensky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Putin congratulates Emmanuel Macron on his election victory in France.
description: Mr. Macron’s opponent, Marine Le Pen, was seen in Russia as a potential game-changing option, amid the threat of new sanctions over the war in Ukraine.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia congratulated Emmanuel Macron on Monday for his re-election as France’s president after defeating Marine Le Pen, a far-right candidate many in Russia favored as a potential game-changing option for the Kremlin amid the threat of new sanctions and in the midst of the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lawrence Gostin and Duncan Hosie
title: No Matter How You Feel About Masks, You Should Be Alarmed by This Judge’s Decision
description: The ruling could prevent the federal government from nimbly responding to future pandemics.
content: Should the federal government have the power to address broad public health emergencies?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gardner
title: The Pelicans Are Finding Their Way Without Zion Williamson
description: New Orleans’s success without Williamson, who has been injured, has raised the ceiling on the team’s potential when he returns.
content: Last month, Zion Williamson threw the ball off the backboard, caught it in the air, crossed it between his legs and threw down a dunk before descending back to earth. This month, he drove to the paint, leaped up from the restricted circle and launched into a 360-degree slam. These were the Cirque du Soleil-style highlights that Pelicans fans had hoped to see Williamson perform nightly after New Orleans drafted him with the No. 1 pick in the 2019 N.B.A. draft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marian Bull
title: The Floodwaters Receded, and the Sun Brightened a New Beginning
description: The move into a Jersey City apartment that had been damaged by Hurricane Sandy in 2012 went well. Then came the one-two punch of Henri and Ida last summer.
content: In Olivia Tarplin’s living room, a pair of terra-cotta-colored velvet chairs face each other as if in conversation, basking in the light from an adjacent bay window. A shelf behind them holds a neat stack of art books and cookbooks, a row of old paperbacks once owned by Ms. Tarplin’s mother, and a bronze bust of a woman’s torso which, though armless, appears to stretch toward the window’s light.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Try Jibneh Seasoned with Mahleb From Kasbo’s Market
description: Benita Kasbo, who was born in Aleppo, Syria, makes the classic Middle Eastern cheese with the spice derived from cherry pits.
content: Benita Kasbo, an entrepreneur who left Aleppo, Syria, as a toddler and lives in Chatham, N.J., makes jibneh, a variety of cheese served across the Middle East. She started making it at home before moving to a commercial kitchen in 2020; that summer Ms. Kasbo, 43, found stores to sell it under the name Kasbo’s Market. Jibneh often suggests feta with less salt, with a softer texture and an affinity for melting. Her version has a slightly sweet nuttiness and is seasoned with mahleb, a spice derived from cherry pits. Suited for Ramadan and the Eid al-Fitr feast on May 1, it marries well with watermelon, is excellent in salads with a shower of fresh mint and is a fine sandwich component when melted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Tell Us: What Is It Like to Be 13 Years Old?
description: The Times is looking for participants for a project on teenage life.
content: The headlines seem to scream at us: Teenage anxiety is on the rise. Visits to the E.R. are surging. Instagram might be harming girls’ body image. Teen girls are developing tics on TikTok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil and Edward Wong
title: Biden nominates an ambassador in Kyiv, aiming to fill a void in the U.S.-Ukraine relationship.
description: President Biden nominated Bridget Brink, the current U.S. ambassador to Slovakia, as ambassador to Ukraine. The position has been empty for more than a year.
content: President Biden nominated Bridget Brink as the U.S. ambassador to Ukraine on Monday, which would fill a position that has remained empty for more than a year despite the critical importance of the American relationship with Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Top U.S. officials in Ukraine.
content: In a trip shrouded in secrecy, Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, and Lloyd J. Austin, the defense secretary, made a wartime journey yesterday to Kyiv, Ukraine, where the president, Volodymyr Zelensky, urged them to provide more aid in his nation’s battle against Russian invaders. Follow the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Villarreal’s Eye for Value Cracked the Champions League Code
description: A Spanish team’s run to the semifinals offers a template for how teams can thrive by turning the impatience of Europe’s giants against them.
content: A great way to understand how it is that Villarreal — a soccer team from a town of only 50,000 souls, playing in a stadium that can hold a little less than half of them — finds itself in the semifinals of the Champions League is to consider the cleaning products aisle of Spain’s leading supermarket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Lauren Hirsch
title: With Deal for Twitter, Musk Lands a Prize and Pledges Fewer Limits
description: The world’s richest man succeeded in a bid to acquire the influential social networking service, which he has said he wants to take private.
content: Elon Musk struck a deal on Monday to buy Twitter for roughly $44 billion, in a victory by the world’s richest man to take over the influential social network frequented by world leaders, celebrities and cultural trendsetters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hard
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘We Own This City’ and the N.F.L. Draft
description: “We Own This City,” from an executive producer of “The Wire,” premieres on HBO, and N.F.L. teams select new players in a multiday draft.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, April 25-May 1. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Chris Buckley
title: Covid Outbreak in Beijing Prompts Order for Nearly Citywide Testing
description: Supermarkets stocked up as panic buying began. Municipal authorities ordered that almost all residents be tested three times this week to contain a rising number of cases.
content: BEIJING — Families in Beijing rushed to stock up on food. Supermarkets stayed open late. Residents endured long lines for mandatory testing. China’s stock markets plunged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: Covid Lockdowns Revive the Ghosts of a Planned Economy
description: China is meddling with free enterprise as it hadn’t in decades. The results are familiar to those old enough to remember: scarcity, and the rise of black markets.
content: Yang Wenhui should be a proud example of China’s rise from economic rubble to global powerhouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: Smeared as a Groomer, a Michigan Democrat Goes on Offense
description: Mallory McMorrow’s viral speech attacking what she called Republicans’ “hollow, hateful scheme” against L.G.T.B.Q. rights has made her an instant hero on the left.
content: As Mallory McMorrow awoke last Monday morning, she found herself transformed into a creature she didn’t recognize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: ‘The Premonitions Bureau’ Recounts Crowdsourcing the Supernatural
description: Sam Knight’s book is about two eccentric Englishmen, a psychiatrist and a journalist, who teamed up in 1967 to study human foresight.
content: Gabriel García Márquez would not sleep in a house if someone had died in it. Colette was passionate about dowsing. James Merrill had his Ouija board. Ted Hughes taught Sylvia Plath to read horoscopes. Robert Graves believed in ghosts. If Edmund Wilson had a dream about you, he’d call you to mull it over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Elon Musk Buys Twitter
description: Plus a lockdown looms over Beijing and the U.S. flexes in Ukraine.
content: Elon Musk, the renegade billionaire, struck a deal to buy the social media company for roughly $44 billion after submitting an unsolicited bid earlier this month. The company agreed to $54.20 a share, a 38 percent premium over the stock price when it was revealed that Musk had become the company’s biggest shareholder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Colin Moynihan
title: Johnny Depp and Amber Heard’s Fight Left Home Damaged, Witness Says
description: At the trial in the defamation case filed by Mr. Depp, a property manager gave vivid descriptions of how one 2015 fight left behind blood and broken fixtures.
content: The property manager at an Australian home where Johnny Depp and Amber Heard stayed in 2015 during their tempestuous marriage testified on Monday about the damage he surveyed after one of their most fractious clashes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Leans Toward Coach in Case on School Prayer
description: Members of the court’s conservative majority indicated that the coach, Joseph A. Kennedy, had a constitutional right to kneel and pray at the 50-yard line after games.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court’s conservative majority seemed to be searching on Monday for a narrow way to rule in favor of a former high school football coach who lost his job for praying at the 50-yard line after his team’s games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Precious Adesina
title: At Ballet Black, Creating Opportunity for British Dancers
description: The company was founded 20 years ago for dancers of color, who are often shut out of the British classical dance world.
content: LONDON — In 2019, the rapper Stormzy used his headline set at Glastonbury Festival to talk about ballet shoes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik
title: China and the World Wait
description: China decides if Beijing will lock down soon
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: The Second Coming of the Lord God Bird
description: New life is everywhere, renewing itself among us, reminding us not to give up.
content: NASHVILLE — Once upon a time, deep in the upland pine forests and hardwood bottomlands of the American South, a magnificent bird dwelt high in the treetops. The ivory-billed woodpecker was a denizen of old-growth forests, but by the end of the 19th century, vast stands of old-growth Southern forest were already gone. A confirmed sighting of the Lord God Bird hasn’t been recorded since 1944.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: State Court Rejects Kansas Congressional Map as a Gerrymander
description: The Republican-drawn map intentionally split strongholds of Democratic and Black voters, a judge ruled. The State Supreme Court will review the decision.
content: WASHINGTON — A state court in Kansas on Monday threw out a newly drawn map of congressional districts as an unconstitutional gerrymander, the latest in a series of similar rulings across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Tina Brown on Harry and Meghan’s ‘Scorched Earth’ Exit
description: The author of “The Palace Papers” takes us inside the power struggles and scandals of the British royal family.
content: Whether it’s the Queen’s platinum jubilee, Meghan and Harry ditching their royal roles or the sexual assault allegations against Prince Andrew, Buckingham Palace has kept the media, and the public, hooked on the goings-on of a thousand-year-old institution. Tina Brown has been covering the royal family since the days of Diana, most recently in her forthcoming book, “The Palace Papers.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tonya Russell
title: Pulling Back the Curtain on Race and Health Care
description: Dr. Rachel Hardeman hopes to inspire others to think bigger about the link, and in turn, solutions that protect both mothers and babies. It isn’t an easy mission.
content: Visionaries is a limited series that looks at figures who are trying to transform the way we live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: U.S. Wants Russia ‘Weakened’
description: The defense secretary’s remarks reflect an emboldened U.S. approach to the war.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Anxiety and Anger Grows Among Children Affected by Shootings
description: “I find it really hard to admit that I’m in pain,” said a 14-year-old whose school friend was fatally shot.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at how recent shootings of children or teenagers have affected young people. We’ll also look at Mayor Eric Adams’s plan to invest $171 million in homeless services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: ‘Crisis Actors’? Where Have I Heard That Before?
description: A journalist in The Times’s Washington bureau explains how some terms used by the Kremlin to deny evidence of atrocities in Ukraine originated here at home.
content: After being condemned around the world for bombing a maternity hospital in Mariupol, Ukraine, Russia advanced a bogus conspiracy theory last month that was chillingly familiar to me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: monsoon
description: This word has appeared in 68 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word monsoon has appeared in 68 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 14 in “How Bad Is the Western Drought? Worst in 12 Centuries, Study Finds.” by Henry Fountain:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Craig Mod
title: A Long Walk in a Fading Corner of Japan
description: As is true throughout rural Japan, many of the once-vibrant villages on Honshu’s Kii Peninsula are aging into nothingness.
content: Stand on the summit of Mount Hinodegatake, look inland across the Kii Peninsula, and there before you are a thousand peaks, crumpled earth like tin foil, frozen roil to the horizon, razorback edges of rock and soil. All muted tones. Turn toward the ocean and you’ll see the jagged coast, wrapping from the port of Nagoya down and around, back up to Osaka Bay, shaped by what’s called the Kuroshio, or Black Current.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: France’s Larger Meaning
description: Emmanuel Macron won, but radical politics isn’t going away.
content: The world’s democracies have avoided a major new crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: After a Rocky First Year, a Cautious Garland Finds His Footing
description: For all of the attention on the Justice Department’s investigation into the Jan. 6 attack, Mr. Garland has focused on the everyday work of being the attorney general.
content: During a recent swing through the South, Attorney General Merrick B. Garland chatted up participants in a police program in Georgia aimed at redirecting youth who had sold bottled water on interstate highways into less dangerous work. He announced funding to address policing problems like the use of excessive force. He talked about mental health support, an issue he has thought about since he saw firsthand how officers who responded to the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing struggled to process the horror.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Bensinger
title: Twitter Under Elon Musk Will Be a Scary Place
description: Mr. Musk has not been a responsible caretaker for the companies he already oversees.
content: Twitter has never been a place for rational, nuanced speech. Expect it to get much, much worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Denouncing War, Ukrainian Musicians Unite for a World Tour
description: The newly formed Ukrainian Freedom Orchestra will perform in Europe and the United States this summer, using music to oppose the Russian invasion.
content: The Russian invasion has devastated cultural life in Ukraine, forcing renowned musical ensembles to disband and leading to an exodus of conductors, composers and players.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Now You Can Make Snow Cones With Your KitchenAid
description: The company has added an ice shaver to its roster of attachments that fits all models of its standing mixers.
content: In time for warmer weather and well-chilled cocktails, slushy desserts and refreshing snow cones, KitchenAid has added an ice shaver to its roster of mixer attachments. Fill the molds that fit the unit and freeze them, then pop them in, activate your machine and a feathery cloud of shaved ice falls into your waiting container. Coffee, fruit juice or other liquids can be used. What a way to serve gazpacho! There are two blades, fine and coarse. It fits all models of the company’s standing mixers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: A Tiny Brontë Book, Sold for $1.25 Million, to Return Home
description: A miniature book by the 13-year-old Charlotte Brontë, containing perhaps her last unseen poems, has been purchased by a charity and will be donated to the Brontë Parsonage Museum.
content: The last of the two dozen miniature books made by the young Charlotte Brontë to remain in private hands, which resurfaced last month after nearly a century, will soon be heading home to the remote parsonage on the moors of northern England where it was made.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Man Who Fled U.S. in 2005 Pleads Guilty to Environmental Arson Conspiracies
description: Joseph Mahmoud Dibee, now 53, was an active member of an environmental extremist group that ignited improvised bombs at animal processing facilities, federal prosecutors said.
content: Nearly two decades after fleeing the United States, a Seattle man with ties to environmental extremist groups pleaded guilty in federal court last week to conspiring to commit arson attacks on commercial and government-owned animal-processing facilities in Oregon and California, federal prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anders Fogh Rasmussen
title: Putin Is Pushing Finland and Sweden Into NATO’s Arms
description: There is a window of opportunity for the two countries to join the alliance. They should seize it.
content: When announcing Russia’s imminent invasion of Ukraine back in February, President Vladimir Putin mentioned NATO 40 times. It was clear he wanted to present NATO as the devil — but it wasn’t always like that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber and Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Union Vote Begins at Another Amazon Facility on Staten Island
description: The balloting will take place this week and could produce the second union at an Amazon facility in the United States.
content: About 1,500 workers at an Amazon sorting center on Staten Island will be eligible to vote this week in an election that could produce the second union at the company in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Amid a Rise in Shootings, New York’s Children Confront a Wave of Grief
description: At least 40 children and teenagers have been shot this year, taking a toll on young people whose lives have already been disrupted by the pandemic.
content: When the thick pall of a gunman’s smoke bombs cleared on the 36th Street subway platform on April 12, at least four of the people struck by bullets or injured in the ensuing panic were revealed to be children or teenagers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilya Yablokov
title: The Five Conspiracy Theories That Putin Has Weaponized
description: The gap between conspiracy theory and state policy has vanished.
content: Vladimir Putin’s Russia is driven by conspiracy theories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Conservatives celebrate Musk’s deal to buy Twitter.
description: One prominent Republican, Representative Jim Jordan of Ohio, tweeted that free speech was “making a comeback.”
content: Conservatives praised Elon Musk’s deal to buy Twitter on Monday, reflecting the way anger at Silicon Valley’s content moderation decisions has become a central issue for Republican lawmakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Kenji López-Alt
title: An Especially Good Tuna Salad Sandwich Starts With the Crunch
description: It’s hard to say exactly when tuna and potato chips teamed up in this childhood favorite, J. Kenji López-Alt writes, but its deliciousness is certain.
content: Who introduced you to your first tuna and potato chip sandwich? A lunchroom friend? A parent? Or perhaps it was your own early culinary invention?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Regulators are unlikely to block Musk’s purchase of Twitter, former officials say.
description: The government most commonly intervenes when a company is buying a competitor.
content: Regulators may examine Elon Musk’s purchase of Twitter but are unlikely to sue to block it, former antitrust officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Ben Protess and William K. Rashbaum
title: Judge Holds Trump in Contempt Over Documents in New York A.G.’s Inquiry
description: Donald J. Trump was ordered to fully comply with the attorney general’s subpoena and will be fined $10,000 a day until he does, though the ruling may be short-lived.
content: A New York state judge on Monday held Donald J. Trump in contempt of court for failing to comply with a subpoena from the state attorney general’s office, an extraordinary rebuke of the former president that came as that office suggested it might soon file a long-threatened lawsuit against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay and Eric Schmitt
title: Seeking Arms for Ukraine, Pentagon Buyers Scour Eastern European Factories
description: Soviet-designed ammunition is part of the ‘life blood’ for Ukrainian troops fighting Russia, and the United States is keeping it flowing.
content: IN POLAND, NEAR THE UKRAINIAN BORDER — Just off a runway on a Polish airfield, forklifts busily emptied an Air Force C-17 transport jet of its cargo alongside a much smaller civilian propeller-driven plane, ferrying pallets of green boxes full of munitions from each to a nearby asphalt parking lot filling up with many dozens of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: L. McCrae Dowless Jr., 66, Dies; Operative at Heart of Election Scandal
description: Federal prosecutors charged him with absentee-ballot tampering in North Carolina, and the state ordered a historic rerun of a federal election.
content: L. McCrae Dowless Jr., the North Carolina political operative who was at the center of a scandal involving absentee-ballot harvesting and tampering that led to the first rerun of a federal election in some 40 years, died on Sunday at his daughter’s home in Bladen County, N.C. He was 66.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Their cover blown, Blinken and Austin pushed on to Kyiv despite the security risks.
description: After President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine spilled the secret that the secretaries of state and defense would visit, the two cabinet members decided to press onward regardless.
content: IN POLAND, NEAR THE UKRAINIAN BORDER — Nearly 48 hours since leaving Washington on what was supposed to be a clandestine mission, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III met with reporters to discuss an operation that was nearly over before it began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley and Julia Jacobs
title: ‘Rust’ Investigators Release Crime Scene Photos, Await Key Evidence
description: The criminal investigation of Alec Baldwin’s fatal shooting of a cinematographer on a film set cannot be completed without key ballistics and other evidence, the Santa Fe County sheriff said.
content: Six months after Alec Baldwin fatally shot a cinematographer on the set of the movie “Rust,” raising questions about who was culpable and how live ammunition got onto the set, the Santa Fe County sheriff’s office said Monday it still lacked key pieces of evidence, including ballistics analysis, that it said it needed to complete its criminal investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Macron’s Win Is Also a Blow to Viktor Orban’s Nationalist Crusade
description: The Hungarian leader had cast his own victory as the start of a nationalist wave in Europe — one that Marine Le Pen would have joined. Instead, Mr. Macron’s victory in France is a win for the European Union’s approach.
content: BRUSSELS — There were sighs of relief throughout the European Union after President Emmanuel Macron beat back a serious challenge in France from the populist far-right champion Marine Le Pen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: 4 ways Twitter could change under Elon Musk.
description: The Tesla chief executive has criticized Twitter’s content moderation policies and advocated open-source algorithms.
content: Elon Musk can at times be inscrutable, and his politics are elusive, which has made it somewhat difficult to determine exactly what the billionaire would do if he successfully acquired Twitter. But over the past weeks and months, as he neared Monday’s deal with the company, Mr. Musk has given more hints about what he would change about Twitter — in interviews, regulatory filings and, of course, on his Twitter account.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Penn
title: American Voters Haven’t Been Afraid Like This in a Long Time
description: Crime, inflation, Russia’s war in Ukraine and immigration are driving voter dissatisfaction ahead of the midterms.
content: In a rare convergence, America’s voters are not merely unhappy with their political leadership, but awash in fears about economic security, border security, international security and even physical security. Without a U-turn by the Biden administration, this fear will generate a wave election like those in 1994 and 2010, setting off a chain reaction that could flip the House and the Senate to Republican control in November, and ultimately the presidency in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Strugatz
title: Is This the Most Expensive Pilates Class?
description: Has inflation hit boutique fitness, or have workouts reached a new level of exclusivity?
content: Devaney Devoe, a product marketing manager who lives in the West Village in Manhattan, is desperate to get into a class at Forma Pilates, the Los Angeles Pilates studio that recently opened its first New York outpost, in SoHo. A 55-minute group class at Forma costs $75.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: April 25, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 25, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: Broadway’s First ‘Funny Girl’ Revival Shows Why It Took So Long
description: Beanie Feldstein stars as the comic Fanny Brice in the show’s return after almost 60 years.
content: It must be a plot. Why else would it have taken nearly 60 years for “Funny Girl,” the hit 1964 musical about the comic Fanny Brice, to be revived on Broadway, when most Golden Age shows with even half a wit left in them — let alone such a fabulous score — have been revived unto exhaustion?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Christensen
title: 7 Audiobooks to Listen to Now
description: Recommended downloads: a brainy campus thriller, a Michael Lewis classic, a search for a missing woman and more.
content: By Guillermo Martínez. Read by P.J. Ochlan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mahira Rivers
title: Sweet and Squishy as Ever, the Gummy Universe Keeps Expanding
description: On its 100th anniversary, the colorful candy has evolved from dancing bears to a booming industry — and for some, a bountiful obsession.
content: Matthew Beverley, an electrical engineer in Mount Pearl, Newfoundland, is known to keep a bag of Haribo gummy candy on his bedside table. There is usually a bag or two in his desk at work. Then there’s the filled plastic bin in his home office, not to mention the scattered loosies.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Workers Face Sticker Shock as They Return to the Office
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 25, 2022.
content: “It’s a perfect storm. We’re ready to get back to work, and now can you afford to get back to work?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, John Ismay and Rick Gladstone
title: Emboldened by Ukraine’s Grit, U.S. Wants to See Russia Weakened
description: Hours after the American secretaries of defense and state met with Ukraine’s president in Kyiv, Russia hit at least five Ukrainian railway stations in rocket attacks.
content: KRAKOW, Poland — The United States toughened its messaging on the Ukraine war on Monday, saying the American aim was not just to thwart the Russian invasion but also to weaken Russia so it could no longer carry out such military aggression anywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penn Bullock and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Supreme Court to Hear DNA Appeal in Rodney Reed Murder Case
description: Mr. Reed was convicted of capital murder in the 1996 killing of a 19-year-old woman. He has challenged the constitutionality of a Texas DNA testing statute in an effort to prove his innocence.
content: The Supreme Court on Monday said it would hear an appeal by Rodney Reed, a Texas death row prisoner who has said that DNA testing of evidence would prove his innocence in the murder of a woman in 1996.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Explosions hit Transnistria, a Russian-allied region of Moldova, amid fears of a new front in the war.
description: No injuries were reported in the area that has a large ethnic Russian population.
content: Explosions on Monday shook Transnistria, a Russia-aligned breakaway region of Moldova that borders Ukraine, and the local government said a security agency building in the region’s capital, Tiraspol, had possibly been attacked using grenade launchers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: Death on the Streets
description: In Los Angeles, homeless deaths soared during the pandemic, doubling from prepandemic numbers. In New York, it was a different story.
content: It’s Monday. We look at why homeless deaths soared during the coronavirus pandemic in Los Angeles but not in New York. And, the Gilroy Garlic Festival has been canceled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: This Eminent Scientist Says Climate Activists Need to Get Real
description: “There are these billions of people who want to burn more fossil fuel,” says Vaclav Smil. “There is very little you can do about that.”
content: “There are these billions of people who want to burn more fossil fuel,” says Vaclav Smil. “There is very little you can do about that.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Antigua and Barbuda?
description: Can you find Antigua and Barbuda on a map? What else do you know about this island nation with almost 100,000 people?
content: Can you find Antigua and Barbuda on a map? What else do you know about this island nation with almost 100,000 people?
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $2.2 Million in California
description: A Spanish-style home in Los Angeles, a three-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a midcentury ranch house in Kentfield.
content: A Spanish-style home in Los Angeles, a three-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a midcentury ranch house in Kentfield.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The New York Times Presents ‘Malfunction: The Dressing Down of Janet Jackson’
description: Jackson was vilified after her 2004 Super Bowl halftime show, while Timberlake’s popularity seemed to take off. A documentary by The New York Times examines how the superstars were treated after their unforgettable wardrobe malfunction.
content: Jackson was vilified after her 2004 Super Bowl halftime show, while Timberlake’s popularity seemed to take off. A documentary by The New York Times examines how the superstars were treated after their unforgettable wardrobe malfunction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Fires Break Out at Russian Oil Depots Near Ukrainian Border
description: Large fires ripped through oil depots in Bryansk, Russia, a key logistical hub in the country’s war effort.
content: Large fires ripped through oil depots in Bryansk, Russia, a key logistical hub in the country’s war effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Kevin Noble Maillard has a recipe for grape dumplings, a favorite dessert of various Native tribes in the southeast for centuries.
content: Good morning. Kevin Noble Maillard has a terrific story in The Times this week about the evolution of grape dumplings (above), a favorite dessert of various Native tribes in the southeast for centuries. Originally made with cornmeal and possum grapes, the dumplings have over generations come also to be made with wheat flour and Concord grape juice. “The older ones used corn,” Kevin’s mother, the late Shermaine Noble Maillard, a citizen of the Seminole Nation of Oklahoma, used to tell him. So his recipe does, too.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In France, a Victory and a Warning
description: Reaction to the French election; churches and the “big lie”; grandparents’ role; a return to Australia; Russian disinformation; handwritten archives.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
